Is it true that there are no solutions to\[n! = x^k\pm y^k\]with $x,y,n\in \mathbb{N}$, with $xy>1$ and $k>2$?



Erd\H{o}s and Obl\'{a}th \cite{ErOb37} proved this is true when $(x,y)=1$ and $k\neq 4$. Pollack and Shapiro \cite{PoSh73} proved there are no solutions to $n!=x^4-1$. The known methods break down without the condition $(x,y)=1$.

Jonas Barfield has found the solution\[10! = 48^4 - 36^4=12^4\cdot 175.\]Erd\H{o}s and Obl\'{a}th observed that the Bertrand-style fact (first proved by Breusch \cite{Br32}) that, if $q_i$ is the sequence of primes congruent to $3\pmod{4}$ then $q_{i+1}<2q_i$ except for $q_1=3$, together with Fermat's theorem on the sums of two squares implies that the only solution to $n!=x^2+y^2$ is\[6!=12^2+24^2.\]Cambie has also observed that considerations modulo $8$ rule out any solutions to $n!=x^4+y^4$ with $(x,y)=1$ and $xy>1$.

This is discussed in problem D2 of Guy's collection \cite{Gu04}.




References


[Br32] Breusch, Robert, Zur Verallgemeinerung des Bertrandschen Postulates,
da\ss zwischen $x$ und 2 $x$ stets Primzahlen liegen. Math. Z. (1932), 505--526.

[ErOb37] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Obl\'{a}th, R., \"{U}ber diophantische Gleichungen der Form $n!=x^p+y^p$ und $n!\pmd m!=x^p$. Acta Litt. ac Sci. Reg. Univ. Hung. Fr.-Jos., Sect. Sci. Math. (1937), 241-255.

[Gu04] Guy, Richard K., Unsolved problems in number theory. (2004), xviii+437.

[PoSh73] Pollack, Richard M. and Shapiro, Harold N., The next to last case of a factorial diophantine equation. Comm. Pure Appl. Math. (1973), 313-325.
